name: 8-hydroxyquinoline
Reason: The basic structure of quinoline has a melting point of around 23°C. The presence of the hydroxy (-OH) group introduces hydrogen bonding, which generally increases the melting point. Based on similar compounds, the hydroxy group is estimated to add around 50°C to the melting point of the core structure. Thus, the presence of the hydroxy group significantly increases the melting point of 8-hydroxyquinoline compared to quinoline.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, quinoline, has a melting point of around 23°C. 
- Hydroxy group (-OH): The hydroxy group can form hydrogen bonds, which significantly increases the melting point. An estimated increase of about +50°C can be attributed to this group. 
- The quinoline structure itself is aromatic and planar, which can contribute to a higher melting point due to pi-pi stacking interactions. This effect is already accounted for in the base value of quinoline.
